Query.SqlString: SELECT Top 32767 ID,Literature FROM Literature WHERE (Literature ='TTNI97')

BibliographicData.Title: Reevaluation of ipsilateral corticocortical inputs to the orofacial region of the primary motor cortex in the macaque monkey

BrainSite.FullName: Caudal cingulate motor area, dorsal bank
Caudal cingulate motor area, ventral bank
Forelimb region of the primary motor cortex
Lower bank of the intraparietal sulcus
forelimb representation in SMA as defined by TTNI97
hind limb representation in SMA as defined by TTNI97
orofacial representation in SMA as defined by TTNI97
trunk representation in SMA as defined by TTNI97

TracerSubstance.FullName: Horseradish peroxidase, conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin

Reference.Quotation: "The electrode was then removed, and two or three sites were selected for injection of WGA-HRP into the orofacial region of the MI.."

"After tracer injection into the orofacial region of the MI, a large number of retrogradely labeled neurons were found in the orbital cortex, which corresponds to area 12 (Fig. 3, sections 30 and 66)."

"In case 546B (Table 1), Fast blue (...) was injected into the orofacial region of the MI. ...In cases 4869 and 536172 (Table 1), combined injection of the two fluoerscent dyes, FB and Diamidino yellow (DY, ...), was made separately into the orofacial and forlimb regions of the MI." (pp. 35-36)

Around the cingulate sulcus, small patches of labeled neurons were found after tracer injection into the orofacial region of the MI (Figs. 4-7, 8). The patches were located in an area corresponding probably to the CMAr (area 24c) and the CMAv (area 23c). The pattern of distribution of patches differed from case to case (see Figs. 5, 8), especially in the caudal part. In some cases, labeled neurons were distributed in the CMAv (area 23c). Our retrograde double-labeling experiments revealed that, in the CMAr, the neurons labeled from the orofacial region of the MI were located rostral to an area containing the neurons labeled from the forelimb region of the MI (Fig. 8). More caudally, however, neurons labeled from the orofacial region of the MI were located caudal to an area containing the neurons labeled from the forelimb region of the MI. There was no overlap of distribution between the two neuronal populations in the CMA. No neurons that projected to the orofacial region of the MI were seen in area 6c, which corresponds the CMAd." (p. 45)

(p. 45)

Our retrograde double-labeling experiments revealed that, in the CMAr, the neurons labeled from the orofacial region of the MI were located rostral to an area containing the neurons labeled from the forelimb region of the MI (Fig. 8). More caudally, however, neurons labeled from the orofacial region of the MI were located caudal to an area containing the neurons labeled from the forelimb region of the MI. There was no overlap of distribution between the two neuronal populations in the CMA. No neurons that projected to the orofacial region of the MI were seen in area 6c, which corresponds the CMAd." (p. 45)

Around the cingulate sulcus, small patches of labeled neurons were found after tracer injection into the orofacial region of the MI (Figs. 4-7, 8). The patches were located in an area corresponding probably to the CMAr (area 24c) and the CMAv (area 23c). The pattern of distribution of patches differed from case to case (see Figs. 5, 8), especially in the caudal part. In some cases, labeled neurons were distributed in the CMAv (area 23c). Our retrograde double-labeling experiments revealed that, in the CMAr, the neurons labeled from the orofacial region of the MI were located rostral to an area containing the neurons labeled from the forelimb region of the MI (Fig. 8). More caudally, however, neurons labeled from the orofacial region of the MI were located caudal to an area containing the neurons labeled from the forelimb region of the MI. There was no overlap of distribution between the two neuronal populations in the CMA. No neurons that projected to the orofacial region of the MI were seen in area 6c, which corresponds the CMAd." (p. 45)
